sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
A new species,
Parahephaestion mimicus
sp. nov.
, is described. Two species are newly recorded for the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais :
Sphalloeme costipennis Melzer, 1928
( Cerambycinae , Oemini ) and
Oreodera omissa Melzer, 1932
( Lamiinae , Acrocinini ). Six species are new records for the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, ( Brazil , Minas Gerais ):
Thalusia atrata (Melzer, 1918)
( Cerambycinae , Rhopalophorini ),
Trachelissa pustulata (Audinet-Serville, 1834)
( Cerambycinae , Trachyderini ),
Ateralphus dejeani (Lane, 1973) (Lamiinae, Acanthoderini)
,
Phacellocera plumicornis (Klug, 1825)
( Lamiinae , Anisocerini ),
Oncideres impluviata (Germar, 1823)
, and
Psyllotoxus griseocinctus Thomson, 1868
( Lamiinae, Onciderini ).
Key word: Longhorn beetles, Pompilidae, Neotropical, Batesian mimicry, Necydalinae

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Hephaestion ( Parahephaestion ) Melzer, 1930
( Cerambycinae ) was proposed to include Brazilian species with elytra bearing costae and metatibiae with dense tuft of short and erect setae.
Hephaestion ( Hephaestion ) Newman, 1840
, included species distributed only in the Andean Patagonian region.
considered
Parahephaestion
a distinct genus. Currently,
Parahephaestion
has three species:
P. brasiliensis (Melzer, 1923)
,
P. malleri ( Melzer, 1930 )
, and
P. zikani (Melzer, 1923) ( Monné 2024c )
.

According to
, there is extensive parallelism in the morphology of the adults of Cerambycinae . They listed
Necydalis Linnaeus, 1758
and
Ulochaetes LeConte, 1854
in Necydalinae and considered that probably the other genera were misclassified.
included
Parahephaestion
in Necydalinae and
in Cerambycinae incertae sedis .

provided the first list of the Cerambycidae from the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, including 83 species.
described
Adesmus lauropalui Monné & Monné, 2017
(Hemilophini) and listed 254 species from the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, of which 158 were new distributional records.
Coleoxestia pubicornis (Gounelle, 1909)
and
Nyssicostylus subopacus Bates, 1885
were registered to the RPPN (
;
) but not listed in
. Therefore, a total of 256 species are recorded from the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça.

Longhorn beetle diversity at the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, Minas Gerais , was investigated between November 17th and 23rd, 2022 . The results of the survey have increased the number Cerambycidae species recorded for the RPPN to 265. Herein, we described a new species of
Parahephaestion
and added eight new distributional records for the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, of which, two are new state records for Minas Gerais , Brazil .

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p:
A survey of the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, in Minas Gerais , was conducted between November 17th and 23rd, 2022 . The material was collected with light traps (Luiz de Queiroz model), active search, and white cloth trapping. The specimens were identified by comparing them with the original descriptions and redescriptions, and the photographs of type specimens available on
.

Specimens were photographed using a Leica DFC 500 digital camera attached to a Leica MZ16 stereoscope, and images were edited using the computer software Leica LAS 3D Viewer and LAS Montage v. 4.7. The photographs were further edited in Adobe Photoshop. The photos of the other species of
Parahephaestion
were taken using a Canon EOS TD Mark II camera, Canon MP-E 65 mm f/2.8 1–5X macro lens, controlled by Zerene Stacker AutoMontage software.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Fifty-three species ( 119 specimens ) of longhorn beetles were collected at the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, Minas Gerais , Brazil . Of them, a new species of
Parahephaestion
is described and eight species are new distribution records from RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça. Two species are new state records for Minas Gerais .

Etymology. The specific name
“ mimicus
” (mimic) comes from Latin, in reference to the fact that the new species mimics spider wasps ( Hymenoptera : Pompilidae ).

Remarks . The species of
Parahephaestion
are possibly known only by the type specimens. We checked four Brazilian collections (CEIOC, DZUP, MCNZ and MZSP) and we only found type material at the MZSP.

The genus now presents four species: 1)
P. brasiliensis
(
), known only for the male holotype, from Passa Quatro, Minas Gerais, Brazil; 2)
P. zikani
(
), known only for two females (lectotype, paralectotype), from Passa Quatro, Minas Gerais, Brazil; 3)
P. malleri
(
), known only for the female holotype, from Itaiópolis, Santa Catarina, Brazil ; and 4)
P. mimicus
sp. nov.
, described in this study.

Parahephaestion mimicus
sp. nov.
can be differentiated from the congeneric species by the coloration (
,
); antennae in males, reaching the apex of ventrite 5; pronotum with four tubercles; and scutellum without longitudinal sulcus. In
P. brasiliensis
(
),
P. malleri
(
), and
P. zikani
(
) the pronotum presents five tubercles and the scutellum has longitudinal sulcus. In
P. brasiliensis
, the antennae surpass the abdominal apex by two antennomeres.

Biological note. Some groups of Cerambycidae that are wasp-mimicking ( e.g., some Clytini and some Rhinotragini ( Cerambycinae ),
Atelopteryx Lacordaire, 1869
,
Hephaestion Newman, 1840
,
Necydalis Linnaeus, 1758
, and
Ulochaetes LeConte, 1854
), are similar in behavior, coloration, and morphology ( Linsley 1959 ). For example, Barriga & Peña (1994) described
Callisphyris pepsioides
and discussed the similarity with wasps of the genus
Pepsis Fabricius, 1804
[ Hymenoptera : Pompilidae ]. The species of
Parahephaestion
has morphological similarities with wasp, with elongated body, short antennae and dehiscent or short elytra (resemble the spider wasp’s wings). The male and female of
P. mimicus
sp. nov.
were found in copulation under a leaf during daytime. At first glance, we thought they were Pompilidae [ Hymenoptera ] in copulation but later we realized they belonged to Cerambycidae . On the same day, we collected one specimen of the tribe Pepsini [ Hymenoptera : Pompilidae ] (
) on the same trail (Trilha Banho do Belchior), which has the same color pattern of the body, including antennae as in the female of the new species.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
As was observed sexual dimorphism between the male and the female of
Parahephaestion mimicus
sp. nov.
, we believe that collecting more specimens of
Parahephaestion
is necessary to better understand the delimitation between its species and if the accentuated sexual dimorphism also occurs in other species.

Two hundred and fifty-six species of Cerambycidae were known from the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça. After the description of
Parahephaestion mimicus
sp. nov.
and eight new records from the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, the diversity increased to 265 species.
Our results revealed undiscovered Cerambycidae species within the RPPN Sanctuary of Caraça, highlighting the need for more efforts to collect specimens in this region.
